1/22 at Noon

China's Traditional Inscrutability: A Surprising Look Behind It

Jacques deLisle

Stephen A. Cozen Professor of Law & Professor of Political Science; Director, Center for East Asian Studies, University of Pennsylvania Law School

Jacques deLisle is a veteran China-watcher, a scholar of contemporary Chinese law and politics. A professor at the University of Pennsylvania School of law, he has a special focus on the influence legal reforms have on economic reform and political change in China. Plus, he monitors the relationships China has with Taiwan and Hong Kong — topics that grab the current events headlines — as well as other international aspects of the giant nation.

4/21 at Noon

Russia

Fiona Hill

Director, Center on the United States and Europe and Senior Fellow in the Foreign Policy Program, Brookings Institution

The daughter of a British coal miner and a nurse grows up to leave England, earn a Ph.D. in history at Harvard and write books and articles about Russia's history, its future and the controversial personality who commands the current post-Communist nation.

3/20 at Noon

The Next 40 Years of U.S. Foreign Policy

Elizabeth Cobbs Hoffman

Dwight E. Stanford Professor of American Foreign Relations, San Diego State University

Elizabeth Cobbs Hoffman, a San Diego professor who traces her career to best-selling western fiction writer Louis L'Amour, began a recent guest column on the Reuters website with "History has no on-off buttons. Change is never instantaneous."

5/29 at Noon

The American Way of War

Dominic Tierney

Assistant Professor of Political Science, Swarthmore College

Dominic Tierney is associate professor of political science, a senior fellow at the Foreign Policy Research Institute, and an official correspondent at The Atlantic. He is the author of The American Way of War: Why We Struggle and How We Can Start Winning Again.
